isis.stitle: TSI 93-02-01R - Tie Rod and Drag Link End Inspection Information

subjectgroup.subject: Tie Rod and Drag Link End Inspection Information

geninfo.para: The tie rod and drag link end inspection information that is in CTS-5027K in GROUP 02 STEERING GENERAL SERVICE INFORMATION AND WHEEL ALIGNMENT section in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual is being modified. It is suggested that you modify page 6 of CTS-5027K Service Manual Section in your Master Service Manual as follows:

figure.caption: Figure 1. Check Tie Rod and Drag Link End Movement

para.emph: Replacement Criteria - Tie rod and drag link ends must be free to rotate within the ball socket. Replace the tie rod or drag link end if there is movement as described below in the axial direction when checking BY HAND on the vehicle.

geninfo.para: If axial movement of 1/8 inch (3.175 mm) or less is found Figure 1, the tie rod or drag link end(s) should be replaced at the next service interval.
If 1/8 inch (3.175 mm) or more axial movement is found, the vehicle should not be driven (taken out of service) until after replacement of the tie rod and/or drag link end(s) is completed.

caution.para: Do not pry on the steering linkage with a bar as damage to the steering linkage may result.

geninfo.para: An alternate method of evaluating the tie rod and drag link ends is by rotating the ball stud with the stud removed from the steering and pitman arms. The torque (force) required to rotate the stud in the end cap should be at least 5.0 to 250.0 in-lbs (depending on ball joint design/manufacturer).
If the tie rod/drag link taper joint is loose or the cotter pin is missing, remove, inspect and replace the components if the contact surface is worn.
For additional information, view the video titled CHECK IT OUT (#TCN-90355) that is available from Westmont.
